text: Hot take. I would say, paid is for everyone. If you look at the way each platform is doing, Google introducing AI, plus with paid taking up the first four spots, you have to scroll pretty far down to get to an organic listing. Meta, it's almost a pay for play now.
speaker: Timothy Davis
context: Lenny asks whether performance marketing is something every company should be doing or if certain business models should focus on other growth channels like SEO, sales, or word of mouth instead. Timothy argues that the digital landscape has shifted dramatically, making paid advertising essential for virtually all businesses. He explains that organic reach has become increasingly difficult as platforms prioritize paid content, forcing companies to invest in paid channels just to maintain visibility.
text_ko: 솔직히 말하면요, 제 생각엔 유료 광고(paid)는 이제 모두를 위한 것 같아요. 각 플랫폼을 보면 구글은 인공지능(AI)을 도입했고, 상단 네 자리를 유료 광고(paid)가 차지해서 유기적 노출(organic listing)은 꽤 아래까지 내려가야 볼 수 있어요. 메타는 거의 페이포플레이(pay-for-play)나 다름없어요.
text_zh: 我直说吧，付费推广(paid)现在是人人都得做的。你看各个平台现在什么情况，谷歌加了AI功能，再加上付费广告占了前四个位置，你得往下翻好久才能看到自然排名的结果。Meta那边呢，基本上就是花钱才能玩得转了。
text_es: Opinión controversial. Yo diría que la publicidad pagada es para todos. Si te fijas en cómo está funcionando cada plataforma, Google está introduciendo IA, y además con los anuncios pagados ocupando los primeros cuatro lugares, tienes que hacer scroll bastante para llegar a un resultado orgánico. Meta, ya es casi pagar para jugar (pay for play).
key_sentence: Paid is for everyone; platforms prioritize paid over organic listings.

text: Instead of thinking about being on top of the page, and that's like ego marketing, I want to be number one. I want to be there all the time. It's about showing to the right person as often as possible.
speaker: Timothy Davis
context: Lenny asks Timothy about common mistakes he finds when taking over performance marketing accounts from agencies. Timothy explains that many marketers focus on vanity metrics like ranking position rather than targeting effectiveness. He describes 'ego marketing' as the misguided desire to always appear first in search results, when the real goal should be reaching qualified prospects who are likely to convert.
text_ko: 페이지 맨 위에만 올라가는 걸 목표로 하는, 이른바 에고 마케팅(ego marketing) 식 사고 대신에 저는 1위를 하고 싶어요. 항상 그 자리에 있고 싶고요. 중요한 건 적절한 사람에게 가능한 한 자주 보이는 거예요.
text_zh: 别老想着要排在搜索结果第一位，那就像是自我炫耀式的营销，什么"我要当老大，我要一直霸占榜首"。关键是要尽可能多地出现在对的人面前。
text_es: En lugar de obsesionarse con estar en la primera posición, que es como marketing de ego, "quiero ser el número uno, quiero estar ahí siempre", se trata de aparecer ante la persona correcta con la mayor frecuencia posible.
key_sentence: Ego marketing focuses on being on top, but relevance matters more.

text: Each platform is different. The user behavior is different. Make sure you're not too hard on yourself if it doesn't work. It's okay to fail because we're either winning or we're learning.
speaker: Timothy Davis
context: Lenny asks for tips on experimenting with new advertising platforms to test for signs of life. Timothy advises that marketers should expect some experiments to fail when testing new platforms, as each has unique user behaviors and requirements. He emphasizes the importance of maintaining a learning mindset rather than expecting immediate success, explaining that failed experiments still provide valuable insights for future optimization.
text_ko: 플랫폼(platform)마다 다르고 사용자 행동(user behavior)도 달라요. 잘 안 되면 자신을 너무 몰아붙이지 마세요. 실패해도 괜찮아요, 우리는 이기고 있거나 배우고 있는 거예요.
text_zh: 每个平台都不一样，用户行为也不同。如果效果不好，别对自己太苛刻。失败没关系的，反正我们要么赢，要么学到东西。
text_es: Cada plataforma es distinta. El comportamiento de los usuarios es diferente. Asegúrate de no ser muy duro contigo mismo si no funciona. Está bien fallar porque o estamos ganando o estamos aprendiendo.
key_sentence: Don't be too hard on yourself; failing means we're winning or we're learning.

text: I always say, where are your users? You will have some data that will allow you to understand that say right now, you're doing really well on TikTok. Some would argue that's an emerging channel right now. Great. If that's doing really well for you, maybe you take... Because that content could be used on something similar like Snap, see how that does for you.
speaker: Timothy Davis
context: Lenny asks about signs that indicate a company has potential for paid marketing to become most of their growth, rather than just a small percentage. Timothy explains his data-driven approach to identifying promising channels by analyzing existing user behavior patterns. He suggests looking at current traffic sources and user engagement to determine which platforms warrant increased investment, then testing similar platforms that might work with repurposed content.
text_ko: 제가 항상 묻는 질문이 있어요. 사용자들이 어디에 있나요? 데이터를 보면 예를 들어 지금 틱톡(TikTok)에서 정말 잘하고 있다는 걸 알 수 있을 거예요. 어떤 사람들은 틱톡을 지금 떠오르는 채널이라고도 말해요. 그게 잘 되고 있다면, 그 콘텐츠를 스냅(Snap) 같은 비슷한 플랫폼에 그대로 써서 반응을 보는 것도 괜찮아요.
text_zh: 我总是这样说，你的用户都在哪儿？你肯定有些数据能让你看出来，比如说现在你在TikTok上做得特别好。有人会说TikTok现在还算是个新兴渠道吧。那挺好的。如果你在那上面效果不错，那你可能可以试试...因为那些内容完全可以放到类似的平台上，比如Snap，看看效果怎么样。
text_es: Siempre digo, ¿dónde están tus usuarios? Vas a tener datos que te van a permitir entender que digamos ahora mismo, te está yendo muy bien en TikTok. Algunos dirían que es un canal emergente en este momento. Perfecto. Si eso te está funcionando súper bien, tal vez puedas tomar... Porque ese contenido se podría usar en algo similar como Snap, a ver qué tal te va ahí.
key_sentence: Identify where your users are; TikTok is an emerging channel for engagement.

text: The number one thing I tell people all the time is use your own data, start with your own data. So take the existing customer base you have, load that up into the platform to build lookalikes. From there, you can do... And I'll use Meta as the example. You can do a 1%, all the way up to a 10%.
speaker: Timothy Davis
context: Lenny asks for advice on running effective 'signs of life' tests when experimenting with new advertising platforms. Timothy recommends starting with lookalike audiences based on existing customer data rather than broad targeting. Lookalike audiences use platform algorithms to find users who behave similarly to a company's current customers, with percentages indicating how closely matched the targeting is - 1% being the most similar and 10% being broader.
vocabulary_highlights: load that up into the platform
text_ko: 제가 늘 가장 먼저 하는 조언은 자신의 데이터부터 쓰라는 거예요. 이미 보유한 기존 고객 데이터를 플랫폼에 올려서 룩어라이크(lookalikes)를 만들어 보세요. 예를 들면 메타(Meta)에서는 룩어라이크를 1%에서 최대 10%까지 설정할 수 있어요.
text_zh: 我经常跟大家说的第一点就是，用你们自己的数据，从自己的数据开始。把你们现有的客户群导入到平台里，去建立相似受众(lookalikes)。然后呢，我拿Meta举个例子吧，你可以设置1%，一直到10%都行。
text_es: Lo primero que siempre le digo a la gente es que usen sus propios datos, que empiecen con lo que ya tienen. Entonces tomas tu base de clientes actual, la subes a la plataforma para crear audiencias similares (lookalikes). A partir de ahí, puedes hacer... y voy a usar Meta como ejemplo. Puedes hacer desde un 1% hasta un 10%.
key_sentence: Use your own data to build lookalikes; load that up into the platform.

text: The biggest thing I want to focus on is what is your thought process when it comes to data? Because I can teach anyone how to do Google ads. I can teach anyone how to do Meta ads. That is not the hard part. It is the data part that is the hard part because there is so much noise going on in those accounts.
speaker: Timothy Davis
context: Lenny asks what type of person Timothy looks for when hiring the first performance marketing specialist. Timothy explains his philosophy around hiring data-driven people over those with specific platform experience. He references the book 'The Signal and the Noise' to illustrate how advertising platforms provide overwhelming amounts of metrics, making it crucial to hire someone who can distinguish meaningful insights from irrelevant data points.
text_ko: 제가 가장 중점적으로 보고 싶은 건 데이터(data)를 대할 때 어떤 사고 방식을 가지고 계신가 하는 거예요. 구글 광고(Google Ads)나 메타 광고(Meta Ads)는 누구에게나 가르쳐 줄 수 있어요. 그게 어려운 게 아니에요. 진짜 어려운 건 데이터(data)예요 — 광고 계정(accounts)들에는 잡음(noise)이 너무 많거든요.
text_zh: 我最想重点聊的是，你在处理数据的时候是怎么想的？因为Google广告怎么投、Meta广告怎么做，这些我都能教会任何人，这不是难点。真正难的是数据这块儿，因为那些账户里面杂七杂八的信息太多了，很容易被干扰。
text_es: Lo más importante en lo que me quiero enfocar es: ¿cuál es tu proceso de pensamiento cuando se trata de datos? Porque a cualquier persona le puedo enseñar a hacer anuncios en Google. A cualquier persona le puedo enseñar a hacer anuncios en Meta. Esa no es la parte difícil. La parte difícil son los datos, porque hay muchísimo ruido en esas cuentas.
key_sentence: Focus on your thought process regarding data; there's so much noise going on.

text: I'm a big believer in hiring smart people and then getting out of their way. But each week having one-on-ones with them, just spot checking things, just saying, 'Hey, I looked at this. This doesn't look right. What's going on there?' 'Oh yeah, I do that on this day.' 'Okay, great. Just making sure you're covered.'
speaker: Timothy Davis
context: Lenny asks Timothy to explain why he consistently outperforms agencies when taking over performance marketing accounts. Timothy describes his management philosophy of empowering team members while maintaining oversight through regular check-ins. He contrasts this with agencies that often spread their attention too thin across multiple clients, preventing them from diving deep into account optimization and maintaining consistent quality control.
text_ko: 저는 유능한 사람들을 뽑아서 그냥 맡겨두는 걸 믿어요. 대신 매주 한 번씩 1대1(one-on-one)로 만나서 가볍게 체크만 해요. "이거 제가 봤는데 뭔가 이상해 보여요. 무슨 일인가요?" "아, 그건 이 날에 해요." "아, 좋아요. 그냥 잘 처리되고 있는지 확인하려고요."
text_zh: 我特别相信一点，就是招聪明人，然后别老管着他们。但每周还是要跟他们一对一聊聊，就是随便看看情况，比如说"嗨，我看了一下这个，感觉有点不对劲，怎么回事？""哦对，我那天会处理的。""好的，没问题，就是确认一下你这边都搞定了。"
text_es: Yo creo mucho en contratar gente inteligente y luego dejarles hacer su trabajo. Pero cada semana tengo reuniones uno a uno con ellos, simplemente para revisar cosas, para decir, "Oye, vi esto. No me parece bien. ¿Qué está pasando ahí?" "Ah sí, eso lo hago tal día." "Perfecto. Solo quería asegurarme de que estás cubierto."
key_sentence: Hire smart people and get out of their way while spot checking things.
